top_comment.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus
*"Humans can't be empathetic and logical at the same time."*

That's completely absurd. Do you genuinely believe that the only cause of 
compassion is emotional force? O.o

http://www.ted.com/talks/sam_harris_science_can_show_what_s_right?language=en

I've already refuted that notion completely with the example of 
dispassionate doctors, which is but one example of a massive set of human 
actions that do good for purely intellectual reasons.

Does a seat belt need compassion to do good?

*"But, if the child were crying because their pet dog died, buying them a 
new dog"*

Put a better hat on your straw man next time. Once again the choice isn't 
between intelligent tears and grinning idiocy.

Even a robot can be made smart enough or programmed in advance to solve the 
problem of the crying child with comforting and patience.

Indeed many objects are far better at it than emotionally saddled humans. 
Witness the power of the stuffed animal, or the blanket, or the cloth 
covered wire monkey.

http://muskingum.edu/~psych/psycweb/history/harlow.htm

*"Edgar Allan Poe's poem, 'The Raven' was crafted with the mood of 
melancholy well in mind."*

And he died of rabies poor and alone having drank enough laudanum in his 
life to kill an elephant.

How mindlessly selfish are you to assert that torturing a man for his 
entire life is worth it because his writing amused you? Jesus dude.

*"To denounce the worthiness of melancholy is to denounce a great portion 
of the art world."*

See previous response.

You may want to keep starving artists in your basement torture chamber so 
you can have fresh star wars fan fiction, I lack such sadistic impulse.

Or does distance and intermediaries and format change absolve you in your 
mind?

Is it different if the product is monocle worthy paintings and poetry? Is 
it different because it's not a basement it's a park bench and a newspaper 
blanket or clinical depression?

Your greed is staggering.

*"We need the irrationality of emotion, even at times, if it compromises 
productivity"* | *"Replace the humans on earth with highly productive yet 
emotionless robots; watch them advance greatly in technology - but to what 
end? If they can't feel, then what's the point?"*

Again with the false dichotomy. An increase in productivity is not my 
objective. How emotionally ignorant must you be to not see that? o.O

Dude, click the links. Get a clue.

You don't even remotely understand what you are arguing against.

http://www.hedweb.com/huxley/bnw.htm

http://underlore.com/paradise-engineering/

Here's one tiny tiny piece:

*"The impregnable well-being of our transhuman descendants is more likely 
to promote greater diversity, both personal and societal, not stagnation. 
This is because greater happiness, and in particular enhanced dopamine 
function, doesn’t merely extend the depth of one’s motivation to act: the 
hyper-dopaminergic sense of things to be done. It also broadens the range 
of stimuli an organism finds rewarding. By expanding the range of potential 
activities we enjoy, enhanced dopamine function will ensure we will be less 
likely to get stuck in a depressive rut. This rut leads to the kind of 
learned helplessness that says nothing will do any good, Nature will take 
its revenge, and utopias will always go wrong."* ~+David Pearce

*"...but from my history of greatly admiring the beauty of sadness..."*

Then you should go work in a prison with all the other sadists.

http://underlore.com/to-the-allies-of-pain-and-death/

*"If you're blind to the beauty of melancholy in art, then it would tell me 
a lot about you; that you lack a certain capacity for emotional depth."*

That "certain capacity" being sadism, and yes I mostly lack it, or have 
suppressed it for intellectual/ethical reasons.

Ironically, if you were right and I did lack emotional depth then I am a 
walking refutation of your earlier assertion that one needs emotions to be 
good and kind and comforting. Specifically I know that a child with a dead 
pet needs a hug, not a new pet. That alone crushes your (laughably flawed) 
argument.

*"Because you come off as an XNTJ type."*

INTJ, obviously.

https://plus.google.com/+BrandonSergent/posts/DNYfzYFeUpr

https://plus.google.com/+BrandonSergent/posts/RnceTBhzM3e

http://www.personalitypage.com/INTJ.html
comments.author: Brandon “Innomen” Sergent

comments.text:
+Brandon Sergent
Humans can't be empathetic and logical at the same time.(
http://www.popsci.com.au/science/humans-cant-be-empathetic-and-logical-at-the-same-time,378496) 
They're two diametrically opposing concepts because; a person with a 
logical temperament would see no reason to stop and comfort the crying 
child - instead, they would find a practical means to solve the child's 
issue. If the child were just crying because their toy broke; great, buy 
them a new one, problem solved. But, if the child were crying because their 
pet dog died, buying them a new dog wouldn't suffice to fill their 
sentimental void - sometimes they just need someone with an Empathetic 
temperament to comfort them, cry with them, and 'feel the feels' with them. 
It goes without saying that Empathetic and Logical temperaments both come 
with strengths and weaknesses.

Writers, artists and musicians exist to explore and provoke our emotions, 
and a great portion of them explore the beauty of melancholy; 
sad music, sad art, sad poems all exist for a reason.
Edgar Allan Poe's poem, 'The Raven' was crafted with the mood of melancholy 
well in mind.
“Beauty is the sole legitimate province of the poem” in general, and “The 
Raven” in particular, “Melancholy is thus the most legitimate of all 
poetical tones.” - Edgar Allan Poe.
To denounce the worthiness of melancholy is to denounce a great portion of 
the art world.
The very existence of art seems to clash with logic and productivity - a 
writer sitting around writing melancholic poems doesn't seem a rational 
thing to do, but it carries great purpose.  
We need the irrationality of emotion, even at times, if it compromises 
productivity, because emotion is greatly linked with the purpose of our 
existence, and life aint all about productivity.
Replace the humans on earth with highly productive yet emotionless robots; 
watch them advance greatly in technology - but to what end?
If they can't feel, then what's the point?
  
If you're blind to the beauty of melancholy in art, then it would tell me a 
lot about you; that you lack a certain capacity for emotional depth. I 
don't intend to come off as elitist, but from my history of greatly 
admiring the beauty of sadness and knowing a great many other individuals 
whom perceive this beauty too - I can't help but sense a disparity.   

(Btw are you familiar with MBTI? Because you come off as an XNTJ type.)
comments.author: Careful Icarus

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus 
*"If 100% positive emotion were possible..."*

It is.

*"...extremely positive people aren't as good as empathy:"*

That's more vagary and loaded terms. The painless adaptive mind does not 
exist yet. Finding isolated configurations where happy people are 
maladaptive at any scale does not undermine the value of happiness itself.

In effect you're deploying a straw man argument, like the whole of brave 
new world.

http://www.hedweb.com/huxley/bnw.htm (This is not homework, it's recreation 
I assure you.)

*"Melancholy isn't just suffering; it's acknowledging the unfortunate state 
of the world rather than ignoring it to stay positive."*

No, melancholy is an unpleasant emotion that exists independently of 
context or intellectual choice.

Does Data from Star Trek need melancholy to make him act for the good? Does 
a dispassionate scientist need to weep at the suffering of the world to 
develop a cure that lessens it? No. We aren't roaches. Tickling our feelers 
isn't the only thing that moves us anymore.

This is an old and busted debate. Essentially you are taking the equivalent 
of the religious position that without the fear of hell there would be no 
kindness.

Such logic tells me more about you than it tells you about me. The bottom 
line is that humans can act in any way under any emotional conditions. 
That's the whole point of consciousness and a neocortex, to allow us a 
class of responses not married exclusively to stimulus.

*"Do you see how positivity and acknowledging the fortunate state of the 
world clash?"*

You're painting a false dichotomy, just like brave new world, that the only 
choices are intelligent tears or grinning idiocy.

To put it gently in the extreme, you lack imagination. Which ironically, is 
another thing that would be handily addressed by engineering paradise.
comments.author: Brandon “Innomen” Sergent

comments.text:
If 100% positive emotion were possible, it would be horrendous; after all, 
extremely positive people aren't as good as empathy:
(
http://bigthink.com/ideafeed/extremely-positive-people-overestimate-their-ability-to-empathize
) 
Their positivity blinds them to other's emotions. Seeing the world through 
rose colored lenses. I would want nothing to do with that world of 
superficiality.
Melancholy isn't just suffering; it's acknowledging the unfortunate state 
of the world rather than ignoring it to stay positive.
Do you see how positivity and acknowledging the fortunate state of the 
world clash?
comments.author: Careful Icarus

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus
Thank you for relaying :)

Terms like "full" and "inauthentic" are loaded and vague. If living in a 
state of unremitting adaptive bliss is "empty" and "fake" then I say to 
hell (literally?) with full and real.

Basically I don't think people making these kinds of pro-suffering 
arguments understand what they are arguing for.

Either their argument is objective, ie suffering leads to survival value, 
or the argument is subjective and boils down to a defense of batman vs 
ironman.

The objective argument is false, since if for no other reason, suicide. The 
subjective argument is misguided since people arguing for these mental 
states by definition are not experiencing them, which means they lack 
perspective and/or empathy.

It is both unethical and illogical to defend suffering.
comments.author: Brandon “Innomen” Sergent

comments.author: Careful Icarus

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus Are you quoting someone? Are you making an argument?

You seem to imply a purely mercenary defense of this particular flavor of 
suffering.

To respond to that for the record whether anyone was asserting that or not: 
I say we are not ants and usefulness is not the end all be all.

Besides, if the state of things is enjoyable, healthy, and stable, I say 
run with it until your intellect tells you to seek change. If it ain't 
broke don't fix it. The status quo is not inherently bad. Humanity has 
proven time and again that even in a state of joy and health they'll look 
for ways to make things even better.

Drunks for example famously scurry around looking for way to compound the 
high. (Food, sex, more booze.) Rich people don't stop once they are rich. 
Fit people push themselves to literally Olympic levels, despite pain, not 
because of it. Etc.

Joy is far more evocative of positive diversity, if checking the status quo 
is the objective.

I'll go beyond that and assert that any negative emotional motivation 
effect has a pleasant emotional functional equivalent. And that's on top of 
an infinite set of possible intellectual motivations, which even if I'm 
wrong are more than enough to compensate for any imagined losses associated 
with the annihilation of all forms of suffering.
comments.author: Brandon “Innomen” Sergent

comments.text:
+David Pearce "Depression causes apathy in the face of this unease, 
lethargy approaching total paralysis, an inability to feel much of anything 
one way or another. In contrast, melancholia generates a deep feeling in 
regard to this same anxiety, a turbulence of heart that results in an 
active questioning of the status quo, a perpetual longing to create new 
ways of being and seeing."
comments.author: Careful Icarus

comments.text:
(Un)happiness and the meaning of life might seem separate questions.  Yet 
as we become happier, life tends to become more meaningful. This increasing 
sense of meaning can shade - in cases of manic euphoria - to intense 
feelings of purpose and significance. Conversely, low mood is associated 
with a sense of emptiness and a loss of meaning, shading into the 
nihilistic feelings of severe depression. True, we sometimes speak of 
"empty hedonism". But if posthuman life is really animated by gradients of 
bliss, then most likely such life will be hyper-charged with significance.

Or in fewer words, take care of happiness, and the meaning of life will 
take care of itself.
comments.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
+Steve Keane Agreed. Even when I was a child and believed in god and the 
like I figured that the fact that I wasn't expressly told by the cosmos 
what was going on it was because the knowledge wasn't relevant for me to 
have in thew cosmos's opinion.

I thought, even if there is meaning, clearly I'm supposed to ignore it or 
make one for myself, etc. How hard would it be for god to come to me in a 
dream or something? Either there is no meaning, or I'm supposed to behave 
as if there is no meaning :)

And then, quite on topic, I encountered the problem of evil. Specifically 
death and pain. Death I could grasp because I had been fed a simplistic 
malthusian picture of human breeding (now proved false well beyond my 
satisfaction by japan and birthrates cross referenced with prosperity 
levels) but pain was completely incomprehensible.

Even as a small child I knew that pain was totally useless. Either it made 
me hurt for tiny non injuries like stepping on a Lego, or it made it harder 
to get well because it distracted or prevented me from doing what was 
right. I have since expanded on that position orders of magnitude and I can 
say with 100% rational conviction that pain can be dispensed with entirely 
right now and humanity would prosper.

So yeah, I agree, the cosmos is plenty awesome enough just taking what 
we're given.

I think more people would see this if given a ubi and permitted to travel 
as opposed to be wage slaves tied to a particular serfdom all their lives.

No wonder people can't see the splendor of the world. They are only 
permitted to visit it if they are born rich or are willing to be homeless.

http://underlore.com/one-possible-solution/

http://underlore.com/bait-and-switch/

*"I not only think that we will tamper with Mother Nature, I think Mother 
wants us to."* ~Willard Gaylin
comments.author: Brandon “Innomen” Sergent

top_comment.author: MassDynamic

comments.text:
+MassDynamic, yes, natural selection is "reliable"  in the sense it helps 
our genes leave more copies of themselves. Jealousy, anxiety, depression 
and other nasty states of mind were often fitness-enhancing in the 
ancestral environment of adaptation. But our genetic make-up 
is causes immense suffering. In future, we'll be able to rewrite our 
genetic source code to serve the interests of sentient beings rather than 
self-replicating DNA.
comments.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
I believe natural selection to be a reliable mechanism. humans survived to 
this day, didn't they?
comments.author: MassDynamic

comments.text:
+MassDynamic, good intentions are preferable to ill intentions. Should we 
load the dice in our children's favour? Or trust a genetic crapshoot? 
Natural selection didn't design us to be happy.
comments.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
i hope when people are given such choice, that they fully understand the 
scope of their actions. "The road to hell is paved with good intentions"
comments.author: MassDynamic

comments.text:
+MassDynamic, you say "unnecessary". But recall almost a million people in 
the world take their own lives each year. Hundreds of millions more are 
victims of clinical and subclinical depression. As the biotech revolution 
unfolds, shouldn't we be free to choose our own hedonic range?
comments.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
i just fear that these unnecessary "modifications" could bring some 
irreversible and undesirable consequences. the "hippy generation" could be 
much more susceptible to suggestion and submission.
comments.author: MassDynamic

comments.text:
+MassDynamic, "forced" in the sense of involuntary. People don't choose 
their own hedonic set-point or pain threshold. In future, however, these 
attributes will be adjustable parameters. If you could pick the average 
hedonic set-point of your future child on a scale of -10 to zero to 
+10, what setting would you choose?  

The balance of Nature? Sorry, could you clarify? How does civilisation 
whose members enjoy life animated by gradients of bliss threaten the 
ecosystem more than a society racked by misery and malaise?
comments.author: David Pearce

comments.text:
+David Pearce i wouldn't say people are "forced" to suffer. just as stress 
is part of the development of humans, so is the ability to "suffer". life 
has highs and lows, to remove that "feature" could very likely upset the 
balance of nature and cause irreversible damage
comments.author: MassDynamic

comments.text:
+MassDynamic, no one is proposing a regime of coercive happiness. But 
likewise, when the biology of suffering becomes technically optional, are 
we ethically entitled to force people to suffer against their will? How 
much, how often, and enforced by what means?
comments.author: David Pearce

top_comment.text:
I've often wondered if sadness and depression were a survival instinct to 
conserve energy -- a way of keeping yourself from expending resources 
trying to solve a hopeless situation.  That's probably why depression (for 
most people) doesn't kick in until after denial, anger and bargaining have 
failed.﻿

top_comment.text:
Thinking the way Emily Dickinson did made me postpone looking for help for 
my overwhelming feeling of melancholy. When I crossed the line and was 
talked into going to a psychiatrist, he asked me: "Why have you waited this 
long?". I answered: "People have hurt more than I have, who am I to 
complain about my pain?".
I have since learned: Sorrow has no measurement, and shouldn't be taken so 
lightly.﻿

top_comment.text:
That Paradise Engineering is quite scary... read a Space Opera where there 
was a race of aliens that never experienced any sort of strife or violence 
in the history of their memory... they were like a bunch of teenage girls 
whose most pressing concerns were the most fickle and shallow things...the 
only way they even functioned as a society were the 'grunts' that basically 
handled all that nitty gritty parts of society: everything from sewage 
maintenance to food production to engineering...while the 'peaceful' folk 
saw them as we do machines or slaves (in an apathetic, non-prejudiced 
manner)... that plus, its just scary to imagine humans with the power to 
re-engineer other being's natural states. Just imagine corporations or 
governments that would make it mandatory to purge you of all sadness, 
anger, and other strongly negative emotions (of which are actually 
catalysts of our most productive times).

I doubt humanity will let itself create some great utopia though; simply 
because we humans cannot imagine, grow, or enjoy a world without violence, 
drama, or some other kind of 'negative' emotions... in fact, boredom will 
immediately run rampant if such a paradise would come to fruition, and we 
do the craziest, most brilliant, and stupidest things out of boredom...﻿
top_comment.author: Erudite

comments.text:
+David Pearce Well said! Great way of looking at it. This becomes 
especially apparent when one really grasps the breadth of this 'Age of 
Information' where Big Data goes further than any one of us could truly 
imagine. Such an overabundance of information will indeed create gradients 
of consciousnesses and imagination as biotech directly connects and 
catalyzes this vast network of knowledge... 
I personally don't trust humanity to make use of it so fluidly as you 
suggested though... I suppose it all depends on how we as individuals and 
influences shape the age to come...
comments.author: Erudite

comments.text:
Historian Lewis Namier once remarked how “One would expect people to 
remember the past and imagine the future, but in fact…they imagine the past 
and remember the future.” The "future" most of us remember is a blend of 
childhood science-fiction novels and Hollywood movies. Yes, life based on 
genetically pre-programmed gradients of bliss might be shallow, but such 
biohappiness might instead be rich, multi-faceted and profound. Coercive 
happiness? It's conceviable; the historical record suggests otherwise. 
Perhaps compare today's biology of involuntary suffering. Would life 
animated by gradients of intelligent bliss be "boring"? Biotechnology 
promises to abolish the molecular signature of boredom, making such states 
impossible. Future life may be driven by information-sensitive gradients of 
fascination. One again, biotechnology opens a menu of options. Either way, 
shouldn't we be free to choose?
comments.author: David Pearce

If you are a living, breathing human being, chances are you have felt sad 
at least a few times in your life. But what exactly is melancholy, and what 
(if anything) should we do about it? Courtney Stephens details our 
still-evolving understanding of sadness -- and even makes a case for its 
usefulness. ﻿

so that we can feel joy... There has to be a balance... ﻿
top_comment.author: Jorge Daniel

comments.text:
+David Pearce You could be right, but let's say fuck you to science and 
concentrate on the real World, do you think the people that are paid 5000€ 
a month are happier than the ones who receive 500€? No... They just have 
more, better stuff, but they are so used to it that for them it's nothing 
special, it's only normal, and they could have better stuff if they were 
paid 10000€... And the same goes for those people, and so on and so 
forth... So no, you can't always be happy, you have to sleep on the floor 
to learn how to appreciate your mattress...
comments.author: Jorge Daniel

comments.text:
+Jorge Daniel, intuitively you're right. But compare people today who 
endure chronic depression. Would we tell them "If everything is bad then it 
stops being bad and just becomes normal"?
Life can be animated either by information-sensitive gradients of misery, 
information-sensitive gradients of bliss, or some mixture of the two. 
Biotechnology promises the ability to choose the upper and lower bounds of 
your hedonic range, and also approximate hedonic set-point. Shouldn't we 
welcome the freedom and opportunity to enrich our quality of life?
comments.author: David Pearce

captions.text: Sadness is part of the human experience,

but for centuries there has 
been vast disagreement

over what exactly it is and what,
if anything, to do about it.
In its simplest terms,
sadness is often thought of

as the natural reaction 
to a difficult situation.

You feel sad when a friend moves away
or when a pet dies.
When a friend says, "I'm sad,"

you often respond by asking,
"What happened?"

But your assumption that sadness
has an external cause outside the self
is a relatively new idea.

Ancient Greek doctors didn't
view sadness that way.

They believed it was a dark fluid
inside the body.
According to their humoral system,

the human body and soul were controlled
by four fluids, known as humors,

and their balance directly influenced
a person's health and temperament.

Melancholia comes from
melaina kole,

the word for black bile,
the humor believed to cause sadness.

By changing your diet
and through medical practices,

you could bring your humors
into balance.

Even though we now know
much more about the systems
that govern the human body,
these Greek ideas about sadness
resonate with current views,

not on the sadness we all
occasionally feel,
but on clinical depression.

Doctors believe that certain 
kinds of long-term,

unexplained emotional states are at least
partially related to brain chemistry,

the balance of various chemicals 
present inside the brain.
Like the Greek system,

changing the balance of these chemicals
can deeply alter

how we respond to even extremely
difficult circumstances.

There's also a long tradition
of attempting to discern
the value of sadness,
and in that discussion,

you'll find a strong argument
that sadness is not only

an inevitable part of life
but an essential one.
If you've never felt melancholy,

you've missed out on part of
what it means to be human.

Many thinkers contend that melancholy
is necessary in gaining wisdom.
Robert Burton, born in 1577,

spent his life studying the causes
and experience of sadness.

In his masterpiece
"The Anatomy of Melancholy,"

Burton wrote, "He that increaseth wisdom
increaseth sorrow."

The Romantic poets of 
the early 19th century

believed melancholy allows us to more
deeply understand other profound emotions,
like beauty and joy.

To understand the sadness of the trees
losing their leaves in the fall

is to more fully understand the cycle
of life that brings flowers in the spring.

But wisdom and emotional intelligence seem
pretty high on the hierarchy of needs.

Does sadness have value on
a more basic, tangible,
maybe even evolutionary level?

Scientists think that crying
and feeling withdrawn

is what originally helped our
ancestors secure social bonds
and helped them get the support they needed.

Sadness, as opposed to anger or violence,
was an expression of suffering

that could immediately bring people closer
to the suffering person,

and this helped both the person
and the larger community to thrive.

Perhaps sadness helped generate
the unity we needed to survive,

but many have wondered whether
the suffering felt by others

is anything like the suffering
we experience ourselves.
The poet Emily Dickinson wrote,

"I measure every Grief I meet
With narrow, probing Eyes -

I wonder if it weighs like MIne -
Or has an Easier size."
And in the 20th century,

medical anthropologists,
like Arthur Kleinman,

gathered evidence from the way
people talk about pain

to suggest that emotions aren't
universal at all,

and that culture, particularly the way
we use language,
can influence how we feel.
When we talk about heartbreak,

the feeling of brokenness 
becomes part of our experience,

where as in a culture that talks 
about a bruised heart,

there actually seems to be a different
subjective experience.

Some contemporary thinkers 
aren't interested

in sadness' subjectivity 
versus universality,

and would rather use technology to
eliminate suffering in all its forms.

David Pearce has suggested
that genetic engineering
and other contemporary processes

cannot only alter the way humans
experience emotional and physical pain,

but that world ecosystems 
ought to be redesigned
so that animals don't suffer in the wild.

He calls his project 
"paradise engineering."

But is there something sad about
a world without sadness?
Our cavemen ancestors and favorite poets

might not want any part 
of such a paradise.

In fact, the only things about sadness
that seem universally agreed upon

are that it has been felt by most
people throughout time,
and that for thousands of years,

one of the best ways we have to deal
with this difficult emotion

is to articulate it, to try to express
what feels inexpressable.
In the words of Emily Dickinson,

"'Hope' is the thing with feathers -
That perches in the soul -

"And sings the tune without the words -
And never stops - at all -"

title: A brief history of melancholy - Courtney Stephens
